questions.question: If I ………………… rich I would donate a lot of money to charities.
questions.description: To talk about imaginary situations we use the simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If you …………………….. me I would have told you.
questions.description: To talk about hypothetical situations we use a past perfect tense in the if clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If I have time, I ………………… a movie.
questions.description: In the first conditional we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: She said that it …………………… my last chance.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we use a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: Will you wait till I …………………..?
questions.description: When both clauses refer to the future, it is common to use a simple present in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: You can stay here as long as you ……………………….
questions.description: When both clauses refer to the future, it is common to use a simple present in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: I will call you when they ………………….
questions.description: When both clauses refer to the future, it is common to use a simple present in the subordinate clause.

questions.question: She surprised everyone when she …………………….. the first prize.
I will give 100 dollars to anyone who …………………… my puppy.
questions.description: Present tenses are used after question words and relative pronouns to refer to future.

questions.question: We will reach there sooner than you ……………………
questions.description: In comparisons with as and than both present and future verbs are possible.

questions.question: I don’t know how I ……………………………….. there.
questions.description: When the main clause does not refer to the future, a future tense is required in the subordinate clause to refer to future.
